blurb: Join artist Anaïs Tondeur to capture the Bengaluru skies in a unique way! In this workshop, you'll get to walk around parts of the city to track and collect carbon black particles from the deceivingly blue skies. As standstill explorers, you will work with the artist to photograph the sky above you—not just the backdrop to our lives, but an environment on which we depend. These photographs will later be printed using a pigment derived from the captured carbon black particles, and will be on display at Science Gallery Bengaluru's exhibition-season CARBON!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: The Sky in Us
venue: Old Physics Building, Indian Institute of Science

blurb:
Join artist Jane Tingley in a public talk as she unveils the fascinating world of a tree's inner life.

At CARBON, Tingley's exhibit includes eco-sensors attached to a tree in the gallery. These sensors gather data around the tree, tracking its interactions with the environment. The data is then transmitted to an interactive installation in the gallery.

Hear the artist share her inspiration for this work, and discover what went behind its creation. Curious about the technology used in these sensors? Wonder how this data can be used? Looking to interact with the exhibit yourself? Tingley will cover all this and more to explore the intricate connections between nature and technology!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: From Roots to Pixels: Where Art Meets Ecology

blurb:
Join us for an evening of quizzing and bubbly drinks!

As you sip a carbonated beverage and answer questions about the myriad ways in which carbon has shaped the planet and its geography, life and the civilizations borne by it.

In this fizzy carbon quiz, you will get to meet scientists, superheroes, extinct animals, mythical beings, and even a few cartoon characters! Kick-off your Saturday evening thinking of, and experiencing all things carbon.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Fizzy Quizzing!

blurb:
At CARBON, Anaïs Tondeur’s exhibit, Carbon Black features the photographed skies of Scotland and Bengaluru, India. The photographs are printed using an ink derived from carbon black particulate matter collected from the atmosphere.

In her artist talk, Tondeur invites us to draw our attention to the sky—not as an object of contemplation or as a mirror to our earthly lives. But rather as the milieu on which, from one breath to the next, our lives depend. Exploring the relationship between air, breathing, art and ethics, she will share the photographic processes which lie at the core of the Carbon Black project. She will also share her experiences on recent speculative and image-making processes she develops as an ecological practice.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Of Pigments and Process: Artist Talk with Anaïs Tondeur

blurb:
Ana Laura Cantera’s work at CARBON, Territorial Inhalations, is centred around a device created along with mycelia (the networks of fungal threads which grow underground) designed to capture and examine the particulate matter suspended in the air we breathe.

At her workshop, Cantera, proposes to make objects from sustainable biomaterials as a way of reducing our carbon footprint as well as creating new materials. In creating these objects, participants can track through the weeks and months of CARBON, the changes in the mycelia and the responses it displays while absorbing particulate matter.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: The Fungi Trap: Creating Mycelium Objects

blurb:
How does an artist, armed with a backpack and fungi, understand the quality of our air? Join Ana Laura Cantera on this artist walk-and-talk around Cubbon Park, where she will share insights from her art practice! In accompanying her, you will get a behind-the-scenes look into her process of creating the exhibit Territorial Inhalations, which will be shown at Science Gallery Bengaluru's upcoming exhibition-season CARBON.

Dive into the technicalities behind capturing smog and suspended gases in the air, using extractors and biomaterials. Immerse yourself in an exploration of the air we breathe, the unseen pollutants that surround us, and the profound impact of our carbon footprint.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Capturing the Unseen: Decoding Air Quality through Fungi Sheets
venue: Statue of Edward VII, Cubbon Park

blurb:
Join us for a captivating cinematic experience as we delve into the intriguing world of carbon through two remarkable films: Copy Shop by Virgil Widrich and Song of Styrene by Alain Resnais. This screening and discussion aims to explore the connections between cinema, materiality, and the impact of carbon on our lives.

More about Copy Shop: Unknowingly, a copy shop employee sets off a bizarre series of events with utterly unforeseen consequences. Through meticulous craftsmanship and a distinctive animation technique, Copy Shop explores the power of technology to reshape reality and the ethical dilemmas it brings.

More about Song of Styrene: Experience a poetic exploration of the industrial world in Song of Styrene. This visually striking documentary, commissioned by a plastic manufacturing company, offers a unique perspective on the production process of plastic and its cultural implications. Through Alan Resnais' visionary direction, the film becomes a meditation on the interplay between art, industry, and the materiality of carbon-based products.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Copy Shop and Song of Styrene: Film Screening and Discussion

blurb:
Did you know that carbon forms more compounds than all the other elements combined? Why is coal the most despised fuel? How long does it take for a natural diamond to form?
In this quiz we dig deep into the structure of carbon and all its forms. Come join us for an evening of interesting quizzing.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Data Mining: Hard Facts about Carbon

blurb: Super batteries, invisible cloaks, spacecrafts—new technologies using carbon could revolutionise these inventions. Atomic sheets, exemplified by graphene—a flat lattice of carbon atoms—are emerging as a one-stop solution for smart materials design. These atomic sheets could become the backbone of future electronics and quantum computing, paralleling the way silicon and other semiconductors transformed the appliances we use today. In this lecture, physicist Arindam Ghosh will explore the role of graphene and similar materials in changing the technological landscapes we know today.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: From Graphene to the Galactic: A Journey with Atomic Sheets

blurb: Can you identify common mushroom species? Curious to know the role of fungi in urban ecosystems? In this foraying workshop, join social ecologist Malavika B and biologist Neeladri Chowdhury to immerse yourself into the world of fungi! Learn about different mushrooms, ways to identify them, the habitats and microclimates in which they exist, and the different roles they play in the ecosystem. Join us to collect mushroom samples and discuss what role they play in the carbon cycle.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Terra Myco: A Mushroom Foraging Journey

blurb:
Although carbon is often associated with negative connotations, it serves as a pivotal element in driving various technological breakthroughs. This workshop explores carbon's role in revolutionising 3D printing by enhancing strength, reducing weight, and enabling intricate designs.

Delve into the world of carbon-infused materials and see how they shape many industries, from aerospace to healthcare. Through discussions and hands-on activities, you will gain insights into carbon's properties and its potential to reduce carbon footprints in industrial 3D printing. Join us in this workshop to challenge preconceptions and explore innovative pathways that use carbon to help create a sustainable future.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Crafting with Carbon: Unveiling the 3D Printing Revolution

blurb:
What happens when you bring together two quiz masters, part-time musicians, dad-joke experts, and scientists? You end up with a jam session full of banter and songs you probably forgot! Join us to experience an evening of performances hosted by Berty and RRK. Come share a joke, sing a song, play an instrument, whatever gets everyone else to join in with you!

Register here to indicate your interest in performing at Science Gallery Bengaluru's first Open Mic night: https://forms.gle/mfaUSvioGmQatsfNA

Not feeling like taking centre-stage yet? Cheer on your friends or discover new talent as part of the audience! Hit the 'Register Now' button to attend this event.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Jam and Two Hosts!

blurb:
Step into the social and cultural worlds of communities who live on hydrocarbon landscapes— villages, towns, mountains, and forests where coal miners, oil rigs, and villagers share a world that is simultaneously mundane and intense. In a carbon landscape, the past/present/future are intertwined in an extraordinary manner. Hydrocarbons remind us of earth’s time in the past, our present desire to consume more, and a future that implores us to reflect on our practices of accumulation. In this two-day masterclass with anthropologist Dolly Kikon, meditate on the layers of relations (extractive/nurturing), feelings (rage/hopelessness), and connections (broken/intact) with land and community. While learning about hydrocarbon landscapes, we will create zines and share stories to reflect on how carbon shapes social, cultural, and political relationships.

Please note that this masterclass will be held over two days and three sessions.

Session 01: Saturday, 30 September | 11 AM to 1 PM
Session 02: Sunday, 01 October | 11 AM to 1 PM
Session 03: Sunday, 01 October | 2 PM to 5 PM
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Living with Oil and Coal: Land, Community, and Storytelling
venue: Old Physics Building, Indian Institute of Science

blurb:
In a world that has grown more dynamic and uncertain, where diversity and differences make way for standardisation and uniformity, this film explores the effects of a rapidly changing landscape on people’s lives and livelihoods. Set in Wayanad, part of the fragile ecosystem of the western mountain range in South India, the film takes you on a journey through a region that is witnessing drastic transformation in the name of ‘development’. An adivasi woman’s concern over the disappearance of medicinal plants from the forest, a local farmer’s commitment to growing traditional varieties of rice organically and a cash crop cultivator’s struggle to survive amidst farmers’ suicides, offer fresh insights into shifting relations between people, their knowledge systems and environment. Interwoven into these contemporary narratives is an ancient tribal creation myth that traces the passage of their ancestors across this land, recalling past ways of reading and mapping the terrain. As hills flatten, forests disappear and traditional knowledge systems are forgotten, the film reminds us that this diversity could disappear forever, to be replaced by monotonous and unsustainable alternatives.

Join us for a discussion between ecologist Samira Agnihotri and filmmaker Sunanda Bhat as they discuss the film and delve into the profound effects of a rapidly changing landscape on people's lives and livelihoods.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Have you seen the arana?

blurb: Beyond dinosaurs, the fossil world holds hidden treasures waiting to be discovered. Studying seashells can help us unravel the mysteries of marine life. The fossil record of seashells spans hundreds of millions of years, allowing us to examine how these organisms have evolved over deep time. Because seashells have diversified rapidly over time, they are perfect for helping us learn how different marine creatures have changed in response to various natural factors and environmental challenges throughout history. The humble seashell serves as a valuable time capsule that enables scientists to piece together Earth's history, study the evolution of marine life, and gain insights into past environmental conditions. Join paleobiologist Devapriya Chattopadhyay on a journey to explore the fantastic world of seashell fossils!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Shell Chronicles: Exploring Deep Time through Seashell Fossils

blurb:
How do you tell a compelling narrative around climate change on social media? Make your carbon stories stand out with this workshop! Learn the fundamental principles of graphic design—like colour theory, typography, and composition—all tailored specifically for climate change communication. Dive into the world of smart data visualisation and cartography to understand urban mobility and carbon emissions. Work with designer and filmmaker Pravar Chaudhary (aka bengawalk on Instagram) to craft your own engaging campaigns!

Curious to know how you can put your learnings from this workshop into action? Check out Chaudhary's work: https://bengawalk.com
email: some email info. this is a link
name: From Data to Design: Citizen Activism and Climate Change

blurb: India’s open natural ecosystems, its grasslands and savannas, have long suffered from a misperception that they are degraded and unproductive ecosystems. In this talk, ecologist Jayashree Ratnam will first unpack the historical and geographical reasons for this misperception. She will then present evidence, to the contrary, that these ecosystems are ancient, biodiverse, culturally rich and highly productive. While they have historically been diverted for agriculture and industry, today, ironically, they are threatened by climate change mitigation initiatives such as green energy and tree planting. They are urgently in need of conservation and restoration action that explicitly values them for their uniqueness and distinct functional ecologies.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: The Savannas and Grasslands of India: Misclassified, Undervalued and Threatened

blurb: How do journalists report on the environment and climate today? What are some of the threats, challenges, and opportunities they encounter? And what is the state of climate journalism in India? Addressing these questions, journalist Sibi Arasu will share his decade-long experience of reporting on the climate. Whether you are a budding writer or a seasoned reporter, work with Arasu to understand how you can start writing climate stories yourself!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Hot off the Press: Journalism during the Climate Crisis

blurb:
From the cave to the gallery—art using charcoal has continued to evolve in texture, form, and technique. What role does this medium play in Indian art history? How have artists used charcoal to create unique works? And how can you start using it in your own art practice?

In this workshop, artists Jayant Hubli and Navin Kushwah will share their journey of using charcoal in their practice. Learn and work with them to create your own artwork that might be displayed at Science Gallery Bengaluru's exhibition-season CARBON!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Lines and Smudges: Exploring Charcoal in Art

blurb:
Today's ecological crises are calls to action. However, to change and appreciate the world, we also need to expand our perception of it. Into the Voids of Perception: On Listening to the Unheard aims to expand the range of perspectives we can have on our environment, focusing on the choices that lie within perception.

Artist Nikki Buzzi will talk about how the act of listening and their engagement with the environment inform their practice. This will be followed by a sound and music experience, with the aim to activate varying perspectives that allow for ambiguity in deciding what's real. The event consists of a journey through particular sonic realities and how we can change the way we approach them.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Into the Voids of Perception: On Listening to the Unheard

blurb:
Embark on a cinematic journey with artist Ursula Biemann as we present a screening of her video works, Deep Weather and Subatlantic, delving into the interwoven narratives of extraction, oil, and water. Biemann's extensive fieldwork, from dense Amazon jungles to frigid Arctic terrains, meticulously captures the environmental repercussions of extraction industries on our planet. Through her lens, Biemann's work highlights the complexity of climate change, contributing to a broader conversation about the intricate forces shaping our global landscape.

Join us to explore the technology behind her research, unravelling the connection between oil extraction, earth systems, and their collective impact on our environment. Engage with the artist as she peels back the layers of her creative process, offering a profound understanding of the relationships between extraction, oil, water, and the evolving dynamics of our world.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Planetary Ecologies: Ursula Biemann’s Cinematic Studies

blurb:
At the intersection of creative and scientific inquiry lies innovative ways to approach and understand climate change. The Speculative Wanderings in Space and Place (SWISP) Lab has created a climate curriculum by working with young adults across the world—be it in Atlanta, Melbourne, or Bengaluru. Learn about the Anthropocene, reflect on your relationship with carbon and climate change, and interact with other young adults to share your hopes and fears about the climate crisis. Join educators Kate Coleman and Sarah Healy to experiment and test out their global climate curriculum!

This workshop will organised on two different days. The contents of the workshop will be repeated on both days.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Hacking the Anthropocene: Climate Stories between Art and Science | Session 1

blurb:
At the intersection of creative and scientific inquiry lies innovative ways to approach and understand climate change. The Speculative Wanderings in Space and Place (SWISP) Lab has created a climate curriculum by working with young adults across the world—be it in Atlanta, Melbourne, or Bengaluru. Learn about the Anthropocene, reflect on your relationship with carbon and climate change, and interact with other young adults to share your hopes and fears about the climate crisis. Join educators Kate Coleman and Sarah Healy to experiment and test out their global climate curriculum!

This workshop will organised on two different days. The contents of the workshop will be repeated on both days.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Hacking the Anthropocene: Climate Stories between Art and Science | Session 2

blurb:
In traditional museums, galleries, and archives, where collections are often inanimate and out-of-reach, how can we move beyond object oriented curation? Research at the Laboratory for Experimental Museology (eM+) blends experimental curatorship with contemporary aesthetics, digital humanism and emerging technologies. We can peer inside ancient objects, scan artworks to the microscopic scale and recreate age-old cave murals in a contemporary setting. These innovations are borne from the emerging field of computational museology, where cutting-edge technologies, artificial intelligence, and data-driven approaches breathe new life into the world of cultural heritage.

In this lecture by researcher Sarah Kenderdine, explore how computational methods are reshaping traditional curation, propelling museums into the future by seamlessly blending the tangible with the digital. She will also give an overview of EPFL Pavilions exhibitions and focus the discussion on Cosmos Archaeology: Explorations in Time and Space.

Supported by Swissnex in India.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Museums in the Age of Experience

blurb:
Calling all curious eaters!

In the recent past, numerous articles, reports, and papers have highlighted the alarming disappearance of bananas. Factors such as pests, infestations, lack of varieties, and the impact of climate change have all contributed to this concerning trend.

In a collaborative effort between Edible Issues and Science Gallery Bengaluru, we invite you to join us on a fascinating journey to unravel the complexities of the banana industry. Together, let's delve into the rich diversity of bananas in India, exploring the varieties available in our local mandis. Our aim is to initiate a meaningful conversation about banana policies, markets, and the future of this beloved yellow fruit. We encourage participants to engage their senses fully, appreciating the diverse range of banana varieties, reflecting on personal memories associated with this fruit, and posing critical questions about how bananas will evolve in the future.

Come be a part of this unique exploration, as we celebrate the banana, understand its challenges, and envision a flavorful future for this happy yellow fruit!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Ripe for Change: A Biodiverse Banana Tasting Event

blurb:
Nearly three-fourths of this planet is covered in water, and within the depths lies a silent force—Blue Carbon. Coastal ecosystems, like mangroves, seagrasses, and tidal marshes, act as guardians, storing and retaining atmospheric carbon dioxide to counterbalance climate change.

Come explore the mysteries that lie beneath the surface in a discussion between curator Damian Christinger and historian Jahnavi Phalkey. This dialogue will kick off with commentary on ‘Blue Carbon’, expanding into the broader context of our relationship with this element as displayed at Science Gallery Bengaluru’s latest exhibition-season CARBON.

Join us as we explore the intersection of art and science, unravelling how these disciplines collaborate to bring cutting-edge research to the public within cultural settings like galleries and museums.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Beneath the Surface: On Exhibiting Blue Carbon

blurb: Join Stefan Kaspar for an enlightening workshop on the wonders of biochar, a key player in the fight against climate change. Discover the science behind biochar production and its application, understanding how this simple yet innovative material can significantly reduce our carbon footprint. In this workshop, you will explore practical methods for producing biochar which demonstrate that everyone, from individual gardeners to large-scale farmers, can contribute to this eco-friendly initiative. Whether you're a climate enthusiast or a curious learner, this workshop will equip you with knowledge and skills to harness biochar's potential for a greener, more sustainable future.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: The Biochar Revolution: An Ally Against the Climate Crisis

blurb: Nonhuman life has traditionally coexisted rather peacefully with human communities across the Indian subcontinent. This is primarily due to the spirituality believed to be shared between human and non-human beings, and the exalted positions many lifeforms—particularly nonhuman primates—have held in the religious beliefs of different Indian communities. This spirit of coexistence, however, now appears to be under threat. In this talk, Rana will briefly narrate stories of how the lives of our fellow nonhuman primates—the bonnet and rhesus monkeys of southern and northern India respectively—are changing forever, and how they are being forced to survive in human-altered habitats by even transforming themselves into strangely human-like monkeys!
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Changing Ecologies, Transforming Lives: Complex Coexistence of Human and Nonhuman Primates in Our Cities

blurb: In this talk, K Ramnath Chandrasekhar will draw upon his work and share stories from the wilderness to explore the concept of planetary stewardship and its connection to justice for all life on Earth. To underscore our interdependence with nature, he will explore "stewardship for ourselves," which invites the audience to trace the connections of care—for ourselves and the environment. He will also share his insights on cognitive justice, and its importance in conversations around the environment. The lecture is a call to action, inspiring individuals to become stewards of the natural world, ensuring a thriving planet for all.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Harmony in the Wilderness: Stories of Planetary Stewardship

blurb: In this talk, Seshadri KS will present an overview of what amphibians are and attempt to excite people to pay attention to amphibians around them. He will draw from his research spanning the last 15 years on various aspects about the ecology, evolutionary biology, and conservation of amphibians in India.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Can We Let Frogs Hop Closer to Our Hearts?

blurb: This talk will largely focus on helping us look at wildlife with a different perspective. It will also encourage people to be curious to discover and learn about the creatures that share space with us in urban landscapes, and how they quietly contribute to the functioning of the ecosystems.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Urban Wildlife

blurb: Central India is a place where a majority of the world's wild tigers live and traverse villages and agricultural lands interspersed with fragile forest corridors that link tiger reserves. Over the last decade, Amrita has lived and worked in central India, mulling over what makes the heart of India a place where humans and tigers coexist. In this talk, she will share these musings in the hope to spark some rich discussions about—'what is coexistence?' and 'who decides how we coexist?' Come for some tiger tales, relatable livelihood conundrums and to consider the many paths forward.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Coexisting with Tigers in Human-dominated Central India

blurb: Our earth is enriched with a huge dosage of carbon. Where does this carbon come from? The sky is a vast storehouse of elements, of which carbon is a significant part. This lecture will trace the carbon in the stars and other celestial bodies. Astrophysicist B S Shylaja will share the ingenious methods through which every dot in the sky produces carbon. She will also draw upon her research to share how we identify, study and examine the carbon above us—an introduction to the huge diamonds in the sky.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Diamonds in the Sky

blurb:
Art mediator Francesca Romana Audretsch engages with artists Ravi Agarwal and Uriel Orlow in this opening event for Critical Zones.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: In Conversation with Ravi Agarwal and Uriel Orlow

blurb:
Are you concerned with ecological and social questions facing the world we live in? Join us for this workshop with artists Ravi Agarwal and Uriel Orlow as part of the Critical Zones exhibition at the Science Gallery Bengaluru –which brings ecology, science and art into a close dialogue. This workshop will discuss how such a dialogue manifests within a research-based approach to artistic practice, share different strategies and methods, and engage with questions of representation and poetics. Taking Ravi’s and Uriel’s works as a starting point, we will engage in short fieldwork and deep listening exercises to cultivate new ways of engaging with the multi-layered ecosystems surrounding us.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name:
Listening to the Land: Poetic and Political Re-imaginings of our Common
Ground

blurb:
Join us for a screening Regenerating Life.The film takes an ecological approach to unpacking the social and environmental crises that confront us, shifting the prevailing climate change story, and offering new, attainable solutions. It tracks growing movements of farmers, activists, scientists, and others working to repair the environmental and social devastation we have caused.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Regenerating Life

blurb:
Curated by Toxics Link, in association with Shared Ecologies, this is a two-package
series of artist films and video works by Indian artists that respond to ecology,
environmental crises and our deep relationship with nature. The films consider nature
and the looming collapse of environmental systems through poetic and artistic
lenses.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Unearthing Landscapes: A Two-Part Curated Film Package | Part 1

blurb:
Join us for an immersive journey into the world of cyanotypes at Kanike Studios' upcoming workshop. This event is meticulously crafted to provide participants with a comprehensive understanding of the cyanotype process, its history, and its artistic applications.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Cyanotype Workshop

blurb:
How are chefs repurposing grains spent in breweries around the city? How can we switch to sustainable lifestyles without breaking the bank? How can we support waste pickers at the grassroots level? Learn all this and more at a panel discussion, which addresses the urgent need to manage our waste better. Explore diverse perspectives, from the ground-level insights of waste pickers by Hasiru Dala to Edible Issues’ focus on minimising food waste. Discover the practical approaches advocated by Daily Dump, delve into the principles of sustainable living by Bare Necessities, and reflect on the impact of youth advocacy groups such as Why Waste.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name:
Wasting Away: A Panel Discussion on Resource
Management

blurb:
Botanical art is the practice of depicting plant species with accuracy and beauty. While such art is often created in colour, this introductory workshop focuses on sketching in black and white, laying a firm foundation for future botanical paintings. It will help you understand structure, volume and shading in plants. However if you’ve been practising a while, feel free to bring along the colouring medium you’ve been using (watercolours, pencils or felt pens only).

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavanas part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Botanical Sketching Workshop

blurb:
Join us for a screening of the academy award winning documentary, The Elephant Whisperers, which follows Bomman and Bellie, a couple in South India, devote their lives to caring for an orphaned baby elephant named Raghu, forging a family like no other that tests the barrier between the human and the animal world.

The screening will be followed by a discussion between the filmmaker Kartiki Gonsalves and ecologist Raman Sukumar.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: The Elephant Whisperers

blurb:
Curated by Toxics Link, in association with Shared Ecologies, this is a two-package
series of artist films and video works by Indian artists that respond to ecology,
environmental crises and our deep relationship with nature. The films consider nature
and the looming collapse of environmental systems through poetic and artistic
lenses.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Unearthing Landscapes: A Two-Part Curated Film Package | Part 2

blurb:
Cities like Bangalore are on a breakneck path to growth, becoming concentrations of pollution, stress, and disease. Episodes of flood and drought demonstrate why we must begin to think ecologically about Bangalore’s lakes, and understand their history, to engage with our collective urban future in Indian cities. Bangalore was built on a firm basis of local ecology, a semi-arid city that created irrigation tanks (now called lakes) from the wetlands in the region, used as commons to foster the growth of settlements and the expansion of the city. Over centuries, as the region became more urbanised, Bangalore ruptured its once close-connect to lakes, transforming the ecology of the city and its periphery beyond recognition. This talk will discuss how we need to learn from the ecological history of Bangalore’s lakes, to re-design the city to accommodate its ecology, ensuring human wellbeing as well as resilience to climate change.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan as part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Bangalore Lakes: An Ecological History

blurb:
Rooted by Dayita Nereyeth is an abstract dialogue between two unlikely
companions – a plant and a dancer. The piece disentangles issues relevant to both
beings: travelling or remaining local, pruning as aesthetic manipulation, and
interconnection. This work-in-progress moves through questions of agency, power,
and balance. Are plant and dancer equal? Can they breathe together?

Delhi by Ainesh Madan is a creative intervention that brings to attention the current
air pollution crisis in New Delhi. The pollution in the National Capital Region (NCR) of
India has risen at an alarming rate over the past two years. Delhi uses movement to
highlight the tension that defines this crisis. The work is a collaboration between two
artists: Ainesh Madan and Nitant Nair.

This programme is organised in partnership with Goethe-Institut / Max Mueller Bhavanas part of the Critical Zones exhibition.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: critical_zones
name: Movement Interventions

blurb: Join Ahalya as she takes you (and your date) through CARBON! Interact with our interdisciplinary and participatory exhibits and engage with activities that will foster a deeper connection to and appreciation of carbon. Who knows, you just might learn something new about yourself and your date!
email: some email info. this is a link
name: CARBON Conversations

blurb: Join physicist and CARBON mediator Parvathy Sekhar from the Science Gallery Bengaluru team as she takes you through the exhibition-season CARBON! In honour of the International Day of Women and Girls in Science, she will focus on the women researchers who have made CARBON possible, and perhaps share her own experiences as a woman scientist.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: CARBON Conversations

blurb: Bruno Latour in his ‘Politics of Nature’ (1999/ tr. 2004) has argued that “political ecology has nothing to do with nature”. Sheila Jassanoff in her ‘Designs on Nature’ (2005) has argued that “biology and politics have converged today across much of the industrialised world.” A recent translation of Latour’s essay “In favour of a dialogue between political science and Science Studies” (2008/ tr. 2023), tells us more about his thinking on Science Studies as possibly the new political science. In this talk, Jahnavi Phalkey will present her response to these arguments as part of an academic debate while exploring their relevance to curatorial work.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Politics | Nature | Knowledge

blurb: This talk serves as an introduction to ecological landscape design. The speakers will be sharing some tools and insights on documenting existing biodiversity on a piece of land and designing for its succession. They will also present a few design stories from projects where individuals who own private farms that exist in gradient zones between reserve forests and urban spaces can contribute towards conservation and awareness of harmonious coexistence with wildlife. The session will end with a short quiz on fauna, which will open up discussion with the audience.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Designing for Wilderness in Human Habitats

blurb: It is not widely known that Lantana, with its attractive flowers—familiar to us from gardens and hedges, roadsides and forests—is actually a relative newcomer to our shores. Its travels began in Latin America, when it first caught the eye of a European ‘plant hunter’ several centuries ago. In this lecture, Ankila Hiremath traces the journey of Lantana, how it arrived in India and made its home here, and what this meant for the plants, animals, and people that it encountered in its new home.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: A Traveller’s Tale: The Remarkable Journey of Lantana camara

blurb: One of humanity’s oldest connections with nature is centred around food. This relationship has shaped identities and cultures across time and space. For India’s small-scale fishing communities, their relationship with coastal and marine ecosystems is critical to their lives, livelihoods, and overall well being. However, while coexistence was the norm, today they are faced with mounting challenges and multiple insecurities. How do we safeguard coexistence in such land and seascapes? This talk will explore the ways in which coexistence was and is woven into fisher communities, the challenges of today and a shared conservation philosophy that should guide our path forward.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: Khane ke liye bachao: ‘meen’ thoughts on Coexistence in Coastal and Marine Ecosystems

blurb:
Since its inception as a map-based platform in 2008, the India Biodiversity Portal has gradually evolved into a dynamic storehouse of primary biodiversity data. Today, it allows people to directly contribute primary biodiversity data while also encouraging citizen science engagement.

The Coexistence Project is a significant endeavour that reflects the portal's dedication to not only addressing the issues of conservation in a human-dominated landscape but also responding to the need for more complex information that reveals patterns and relationships within an ecosystem. This talk will explore the portal and the project in tandem, to think about the coexistence dynamics between biodiversity and human activities by capturing intricate aspects of species attributes, habitat characteristics, and ecological interactions.

As cities such as Bengaluru undergo rapid urbanisation, the resulting habitat and biodiversity loss pose challenges for coexistence. Documenting incidents of this interaction in a structured manner becomes imperative for effective conservation strategies and urban planning that foster harmonious cohabitation.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: The India Biodiversity Portal, Citizen Science, and Coexistence

blurb: India’s open natural ecosystems, its savannas and grasslands, have long suffered from a misperception that they are degraded and unproductive ecosystems. In this talk, Jayashree Ratnam will unpack the historical reasons for this misperception, and present evidence, to the contrary, that these ecosystems are ancient, biodiverse, culturally rich and highly productive. Today, they are urgently in need of conservation and restoration action that explicitly values them for their open-ness, uniqueness and distinct functional ecologies.
email: some email info. this is a link
label: common_ground
name: The Savannas and Grasslands of India: Misclassified, Undervalued and Threatened

blurb: At a time of global urgency for action on the climate crisis, can creativity, collaboration and experimentation help inspire a better future? Join Dr Ryan Jefferies, to learn how Science Gallery Melbourne at the University of Melbourne has boldly begun a journey to promote social change. From First Nations people’s knowledge and culture, to urine batteries that charge your mobile phone, to 3D-printed edible insects. Learn how innovation, speculation and provocation by artists and scientists are fostering youth-led action to tackle climate change and promote greater sustainability in Australia and around the world.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: Feeling the Heat

blurb: Did you know that Indian Ink was actually invented in China? Did you know that the man who discovered oxygen also made the first carbonated drink? Did you know that coal is the biggest freight earner for the Indian Railways? Do you know what your nail polish is made of? These were some of the questions asked in previous quizzes. The first in-house quiz at the Science Gallery Bengaluru, and the third at CARBON, will draw from the sciences, the arts, the coal mines and other walks of life, very much like the Dire Straits song referenced in the title. This National Science Day, come on over for an evening of more such fun facts about carbon.
email: some email info. this is a link
name: In the Gallery...A Fine Coal Miner

blurb:
Seen the virtual reality exhibit Carbon Nanoverse at CARBON, Science Gallery Bengaluru? Curious to know about the science behind it? Join us for a talk with materials scientist Dr Jacob Martin, who is part of the two-person team behind the exhibit!

Martin will focus on the science behind the lithium-ion batteries that are revolutionising our transport and are set to transform our electrical grid. But how do they work at the atomic scale? We will experience the atomic structure of a battery using computer visualisations and 3D glasses! Alongside this atom eye view, Jacob will share the materials science that led to the discovery of the battery, and his recent work on manufacturing battery grade graphite.
name: Into the Nanoverse: An Atomic View of a Battery

blurb:
Nanoscale phenomena are so small that they require complex instruments to study and observe them. But how do you experience these phenomena outside of the laboratory? How can you translate data from the lab into a sound installation?

This workshop explores the artistic practices used to create the soundscape for the installation Movement 1: Nanomorphology featured at CARBON. The artist will share digital tools made in Max MSP, and run a session on how to use the tools with text files of two-dimensional scientific, numerical data.
name: From Data to Sound: The Making of 'Movement 1: Nanomorphology'

blurb: Nature has always been an incredible source of inspiration. Join wildlife artist Sangeetha Kadur on an exploration walk with nature as we immerse ourselves in our surroundings and capture the natural world in our sketchbooks. Through this workshop, discover the art of seeing, sketching and note-taking. Learn the meticulous and fun ways of filling up your journal pages with interesting observations and nature stories.
name: A Sketchbook with Nature

blurb: This International Women's Day, join us at 6 PM for a special walkthrough that goes beyond the conventional, focusing on the creativity and brilliance of women artists and scholars participating in CARBON. Explore the perspectives and works of 15 talented women situated at the intersection of art, science, and culture under the spotlight of "Walking the Talk: Women at CARBON."
name: Walking the Talk

blurb: How do artists and scientists collaborate to create immersive experiences? Join Jacob Martin and Andrea Rassell as they discuss the behind-the-scenes creation of Carbon Nanoverse, a cutting-edge Virtual Reality (VR) project blending media arts, physical chemistry, and game theory. Dive into a hands-on demonstration of stereoscopic 3D video for VR, explore easily accessible media tools for science projects, and embark on a guided tour of the immersive VR experience.
name: Carbon Nanoverse: 3D Visualisations in Art
